reviewText: I agree with the reviewer who said everyone interprets the book in a different way.  I've always been slightly irritated with the other versions that render one of the most passionate books so tame and mannerly.  Jane Eyre is not a Jane Austen novel.  It is over the top and gothic and melodramatic. Jane and Rochester are two passionate creatures in the book--they are always storming and raging and lightning is symobolically burning trees next to them--but in the movies they are so chaste.  I was thankfully surprised that in this one they are touchy-feely.  In the book, when he is trying to persuade her to stay with him, there is a lot of crushing her to him going on.  I'm glad they showed that in this version.  I really believed these two were in love, mentally, emotionally, and physically.I think it's funny that a couple people said they were too good looking but nobody mentions that the actress in the Timothy Dalton version looks about 38.  I never could believe it when she says she's 18.  And she has none of the impetuousness and rage that young Jane Eyre has.  I loved this one.  I thought she captured all the power and passion surging in Jane's soul.  And I like that she is cute to us but would have been considered ugly by Victorians.  That is how I always pictured Jane--as somebody who didn't live up to her age's standard of beauty, whereas Blanche is supposed to be the epitome of that ideal.I thought this version was more in the spirit of the book than any of the others (a spirit of passion and vehemence and rage).  I would recommend it.

reviewText: The most blatant flaw with this production was the casting:  The handsome Toby Stephens (like the gorgeous Timothy Dalton in the earlier BBC production) is totally inappropriate because Bronte depicts Rochester as an ugly, Vulcan-like man of medium height.  (Also, Stephens' acting (he's not convincing as a man who has lived in empty misery for 15 years) is mediocre, so he's not credible on that score, either.)  In the novel Jane is a small woman with irregular features.  Ruth Wilson is a tall beauty.  One of the things Rochester and Jane understand about one another is how it feels to be considered ugly relative to the population at large.  As a couple, Wilson and Stephens would easily fit in at a Hollywood party.  Clearly the idolatry of the modern age influenced the director, who, given the BBC's reputation for quality television should have known better.  The cynical view is that Stephens' status as the son of renowned British actress Dame Maggie Smith influenced his casting.A lot of time was spent highlighting the romance scenes between Rochester and Jane, Celine and Rochester, St. John and Miss Oliver, and even Bertha and Rochester. I believe this was done to attract young women viewers who will love these scenes -- and buy the DVD.  We don't, however, see much of (1) Bronte's criticism of the Church (i.e., St. John's coldness of heart, and its inconsistency with Jesus' character, or Mr. Brocklehurst's cruelty), or (2) the persistence of good in an evil environment (as displayed in Bessie, Ms. Temple, Helen Burns), both major themes in the novel.  Clearly, commercial appeal won out over artistic quality and the author's intent.Though the production is not embarrassing (notwithstanding the acting of several characters is not of the caliber one expects in a BBC production), it is disappointing in its blatant refusal to honor the key features of the novel (i.e., ugly people can find love, too; hypocrisy and cruelty in the Church of England; child abuse; Christian duty to do right when life has been hard).  (Again, these themes won't sell DVDs.) The Sorcha Cusack/Michael Jayston production (1973) is the most faithful to the novel and an absolute delight to watch.  This and the Timothy Dalton/Zelah Clarke production are the best versions of the great story.

reviewText: Note:I have now seen ALL the color adaptations of Jane Eyre. While I liked this adaptation better than the 1981 and 1996 adaptations - and about equally well as the 1997 A&E; adaption - I thought the film fell short of the 1973 or 1983 BBC adaptations.My primary problem with this film is that it seems to modernize the story. In other words, the language and mannerisms of the actors appear more 21st century than 19th century. Now, there are many examples of this. I will list a few.1.2006 adaptation has Rochester hire someone to play a fortune-telling gypsy. I believe the reasoning behind this is that it would appear more logical to a 21st century audience that is very critical of the supernatural. (i.e. 21st century viewer might say, how could Blanche NOT know the gypsy woman is Rochester!!) However, in the early 1800s, I think a man like Rochester could have pulled off dressing like a gypsy because of the religious superstition of that period.2.Blanche is kinder is this adaptation than the 1973 or 1983. I guess the 21st century young people would be amazed at the rudeness Blanche conveyed in the earlier adaptations. Therefore, the scriptwriters softened her image.3.In 1973,Michael Jayston presents a somewhat vulcan Rochester. Both the 1983 and 2006 adaptation make Rochester appear pretty. However, the 1983 DOES create a vulcan Rochester AFTER the fire at Thornfield. Therefore, in a way, they made up for his handsomeness before the accident. However, the 2006 just makes Rochester too handsome for the whole film.4.In Oliver Twist, the classic lines "Please, sir, I want some more" and "It's more no than yes Bill" are remembered. I could not imagine any credible adaptation revising these expressions to "I would like to eat some more gruel" or "I do not want to go to court to see if Oliver is there." Likewise, this adaptation changes many of the classic and memorable phrases from the novel. For example, Rochester calls Jane "a witch" rather than "an elf," swears by using God instead of deuce (devil).Final Thoughts:Jane Eyre (1973) and (1983) are much more loyal to the original story-line. Because of this, it is possible that Masterpiece Theatre decided to change the story a little to appeal to viewers who wanted a change. I do not criticize the adaption nearly so much as I do the Oliver Twist (2007) BBC adaptation. However, I just personally feel that for me the 1973 and 1983 are better, more loyal productions. Since I am a literalist, I think they are more worth my time and/or money.

reviewText: Truth be told, I didn't read the book until last year. To date I have seen 6 other "Jane Eyre" adaptations (4 movies & 2 miniseries).This adaptations screen writer is Sandy Welsh, who has written 2 of my favorite miniseries: "North & South" '04 (the Elizabeth Gaskell novel)- a 1st place tie between "Pride & Prejudice" '95, as being my most favorite period drama to date! And (Jane Austen's) "Emma" '09.So for me, she's set the bar quite high in her productions.Sadly, this miniseries pales in comparison to the faithfulness of the previous two BBC miniseries: 1973 & 1983.While the events are substantially in order, the dialogue is modernized (aka "dumbed down").The chemistry (or in this case, the overt portrayal of physical attraction) is believable enough, but I guess that's because it's pushed in the viewers face every few minutes. Sadly this is a misinterpretation of the story-- being Rochester & Jane are both described in less attractive terms; so their mutual attraction lies in their personality & intellectual connection.I felt this "Rochester" (Toby Stephens) lacked the complexity of the books character. His "brooding" lasts about 5-10 minutes, then he turns into a ridiculous lovesick whelp (but to be fair, part of the blame could lie in script, and direction). In the book, "Rochester" is very careful at concealing his true feelings until the proposal scene; not so with this.Ruth Wilson's portrayal of "Jane" was a fair bit better (likely in my top 3); although her appearance is much prettier than her book counterpart.The major things I didn't care for are (**SPOILER ALERT**):- Miss Temple was missing from Jane's extremely shortened and glossed over Lowood experience (something the other 2 mini's included); who was very much a guiding force, and savior for Jane!In fact, it was after Miss Temple married and left, that Jane decided to leave herself.- Instead of the game of charades in the book, they replaced it with the Victorian version of Ouija (which I skipped over).The charades scene was important, because one of them happened to depict Rochester & Miss Ingram being married (thus stirring a pang of emotion in Jane).- An actual Gypsy woman was hired by Rochester, instead of him dressing up and pretending to be one. A major cop-out if you ask me, being the other 2 miniseries faithfully portrayed this important scene.It's Rochester's rather unconventional (and somewhat comical) attempt at ascertaining her inner feelings towards him.- Rochester's plea for Jane to stay after the Bertha revelation, was seriously altered from the book, and sadly cheapened by spicing it up.That whole bed scene simply did not happen in the book; at this point Jane shunned Rochester's displays of affection!Again, refer to the '73 & '83 adaptations, if you want an accurate depiction!(I also think the 2011 movie captured this crucial scene much better, despite it being shortened.)- The glimpse of Bertha's licentious behavior after her marrying Rochester was utterly gratuitous, again, another ridiculous attempt at spicing the story up; a simple verbal explanation would have sufficed!In conclusion, I feel this miniseries had the potential to be so much better than it was. If you really desire an accurate depiction, look elsewhere ('73 or '83 miniseries, or the condensed 2011 movie).On the other hand, if you don't mind a modernized soaped up version of "Jane Eyre", then look no further!

reviewText: I was so excited to learn of a new production of my favorite book, and to add another DVD to my Jane Eyre film collection.  I'm truly sad to say this is just about the worst version of the nine, yes, nine adaptations.  The most faithful version remains the 1983 BBC production starring Timothy Dalton & Zelah Clark.The Masterpiece Theatre Jane Eyre misses Bronte's all important social commentary on the abuse & neglect of children, the status of women, and the Victorian view of mental health care.  Bronte tackled human rights head on:  her heroine is a, if not 'the' proto-feminist, her progressive hero a  humanitarian.  Sadly, the foundation of the novel is seriously diminished in the mini series with the first twelve chapters covering Jane's childhood are given the barest attention.(Circa 1850 women and children were regarded as property, women being thought to be biologically inferior.  Being a governess was to be a servant: after teaching was over for the day, a governess then took on menial labor, and at the end of long work day retired to a bed in the attic servants quarters.  Re. women & mental health issues, a male relative, notably a husband, could rid himself of the expense of a wife he didn't like byhaving her diagnosed with 'hysteria'.  She would then be removed to an institution such as the infamous Bedlam where she would find herself housed with the so-called 'insane' and 'mentally deficient'.  Beyond thechance of suffering physical assault by inmates, meager nutrition, unheated housing, the inmate's life wasshortened by poor sanitation leading to dysentary (24/7 diahrria), consumption (tuberculosis), etc..  Rochesters' placing Bertha under the care of a private nurse within his home is truly an extraordinary humanitarian act.  Final sidebar:  in 1850 England it was against the law to beat a horse but there was no lawagainst beating a woman).The casting is strange.  Ruth Wilson is far too tall to play Jane, and she looks vigorous enough to build Thornfield in the morning and plow fields in the afternoon. Toby Stephens' goofy Rochester is downright comic:  there are moments when you half expect him to do a Monty Python "wink, wink, nod, nod".  Togetherthey lack the chemistry necessary to meet the demands of one of English literature's most passionate couples.  When Wilson & Stevens touch, she touches his shirt with her hand but does not clasp his arm.  And, with the notable exception of the excellent portrayal of Blanche, the supporting cast is dull especially when compared to the stunning supporting cast in A&E;'s Jane Eyre with its near perfect portrayal of 10 year old Jane.Beyond a weak cast, the most serious flaw with the production is the complete mess of a screenplay which hacks up the novel into bits & pieces, and relies on awkward flashbacks and discordant dream sequences.For those new to Jane Eyre, the Masterpiece Theatre production may seem wildly romantic but for those who go on to read Bronte's novel you will be richly rewarded with a far deeper & passionate love story.

reviewText: I would give it 3 and 1/2 stars.  I was pleasantly surprised although I personally can't give it 5 stars for a number of reasons. I think those who have only seen the 2 hours versions and not the Dalton version and/or read the book will like it a lot. For most (not all) of those who've seen or read the latter they'll not be as overwhelmed.Because the Dalton/Clarke adaptation is closer to the book in atmosphere and dialogue, it truly epitomizes the Gothic romance and atmosphere of the book with the sexy, smouldering broodiness of Mr. Rochester, the soft-spoken introverted fairylike creature of the strong-minded Jane and the combination of the dark cloud of mystery hanging over Thornfield Hall and it's master.  For Masterpiece Theatre to cut out some of THEE most important parts of Mr. Rochester's introspective dialogue with Jane as she fell in love with the glimpse of the redemptive man she saw in the tortured soul, was a crime to say the least. It was so important to the story and there were so many hours in which to work with.You kind of know where things stand early on in this version.  If you like things to be a little more obvious as opposed to subtle, then this one is definitely for you!I felt Toby Stephens did a great job and he actually portrayed SOME type of emotion unlike Orson Welles, William Hurt and others who clung too strongly in my opinion to the angry/brooding side of Mr. Rochester.Mr. Rochester was a combination of moody, happy (with Jane), tumultuous and quietly introspective. Toby Stephens is never quite the "peculiar" Mr. Rochester that Mrs. Fairfax initally describes to Jane, nor is he the moody person Jane describes in the book as being one day kind to her, then unkind during some of their earlier meetings. This Mr. Rochester appears more lonely and sad, not necessarily brooding.For a friend, that I asked (more like begged) to watch because she had never read or watched Jane Eyre, this version (outside of the surprise of Bertha) left little surprise for her by way of their feelings because of the added scenes of his impatient treatment of Blanche Ingram and also the numerous scenes of he and Jane walking and talking alone out in the open as opposed to meeting in secret due to unforseen circumstances.  The proposal under the tree was very anti-climatic to her because of this. In the book/Dalton versions you are feeling Jane's anguish right up until the time he makes her finally open up and express her feelings for him.  Up until then you aren't sure if he is getting married or not.  When Jane struggles with him under the tree in this version, it's almost pointless as they already have pretty much let the other know their feelings due to their established companionship.I had to LAUGH OUT LOUD at this portrayal of Bertha.  The book had her practically running around on all fours like a beast with her hair a tangled mess (as did the Dalton version), but this version had a very lovely Bertha who had a temper tantrum at the end. No where near the look and lunacy portrayed in the book in order that you could truly sympathize with the plight of Mr. Rochester trying to find happiness in a plain governess who had a gentle spirit and light about her.I thought Ruth Wilson's acting was very good as she worked with the script she was given.  Her Jane called for Jane's outward expressions and actions to be far more assertive and impertinent than that of the time period and the book's Jane Eyre. For the most part, the book's Jane's inner thoughts were very passionate and not said aloud until the proposal scene, hence his painstaking attempts to draw her out.  With that said, she worked the adaptation she was given quite well.Also in this version, the gypsy scene appeared more as a simple joke played on all of the guests as opposed to what it truly was in the book and Dalton version - a plot by Mr. Rochester to draw out Jane's feelings for him in order to help her realize that outside of her stubborness and self-preservation, happiness was within her reach.  The dialogue in the book and Dalton scene spoke volumes as to how he truly recognized Jane's deeply conditioned thinking of being unworthy of happiness and reciprocated love.  It truly is an unforgettable scene due to the depth of the conversation and the humorous depths he sank to get into her head and have her express herself. The gypsy scene also was a way to expose Blanche Ingram for the "mercenary"  she actually was. The book and Dalton's Mr. Rochester is much more of a scoundrel with a heart. This one already appears to be "saved" and not really seen as a scoundrel. He's more of a man whose had a few bad breaks and easily redeemable.Although as someone else alluded to, the physcial scenes are very harmless when generally speaking of Hollywood standards today, they are still SORELY misplaced in the Jane Eyre scheme of things.  The movie studios for some reason do not "get" there can be passion without laying on top of one another which would have never happened with the book's Jane character for the sake of righteousness and not flaming her own raging feelings. In that regard, I feel the studios do not have faith in their viewing audience to clearly see the underlying passions building up with looks and words exchanged between the two.  Can you imagine if the studios took such liberties with Pride and Prejudice and showed Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy doing that? Elizabeth was far more bold and assertive than Jane, yet they have Jane doing just that in this version while in a closed room, then outside on the lawn before marriage.  Jane Eyre? It would never happen... although the reader/viewer would know she'd wish it. Oh well.I guess the most positive thing I can say is the acting is top-notch and it's better than the other versions outside of the Dalton/Clarke adaptation - which still remains my favorite at this time.

reviewText: Here in the United States, we have the NFL, Peyton Manning and his brother Eli as definitions of the alpha male species.  However, our cousins across the pond in England get to have Edward Rochester and Toby Stephens. Stephens gives the perfect alpha-male performance of Rochester in this movie by the BBC to the point that you cannot imagine EVER anyone else performing this role.  And, major newspaper reviewers said the same thing. After my husband saw it, he couldn't ever imagine George C. Scott in the role either (he said, "Ewww, no way!") - that's how much Stephens makes this role his own. It's a difficult thing to usurp performances of the same role by two MAJOR Hollywood actors but Stephens definitely does that in this movie with great ease.  Trying to imagine someone else perform the role after Stephens would be like enduring an American Idol contestant trying to perform "Staying Alive" by the Bee Gees or Elvis' "Jailhouse Rock."  Some performances stand alone throughout time, and Stephens' portrayal of Rochester in this film is definitely one of those performances.Here's something you probably wouldn't imagine from a movie like this. We live in a very golf and equestrian-oriented community and when Rochester rides in on that gorgeous black horse, dressed in black himself, well, a bunch of nine-year-old boys here just thought he was the consummate picture of cool!  If you're now shuddering at the thought of me allowing such young boys to watch this entire movie, well, that's what the fast forward button on the remote is for!  Besides, they didn't like any scene unless Rochester was in it and well, they OF COURSE think it's cool to watch Bertha burn the house down and jump off the roof.  Gotta be a boy, I guess!  But again, that's because of Stephens' ability to captivate an audience and pull them into the production.  Experienced theatre actors stand way above our Hollywood actors - these boys just couldn't turn away from this movie once they started watching it. Can you believe this? They want to read the book! Now to me, if I was an actor and could merit that kind of attention for a classic novel from such a young audience, I could retire with great happiness!  Can't wait until they have to read this book in high school and get to ruin the ending for the rest of the class!Keep this in mind too - this movie is now five years old and Amazon still runs out of stock on it, and people are still writing reviews for it!  I stumbled upon this movie one night on public television while Christmas shopping AND during a commercial (and it's a RARE thing that I even turn the television on).  Being thus distracted and with my back to the television, I hadn't realized the movie had come back on.  Before this movie, I had never seen Toby Stephens before in anything, but what made me turn around and watch was his voice. So much for Christmas shopping!  Since they delayed showing the second half to "well, the next time Masterpiece Theatre is on, we'll show the rest," I went ahead and ordered it on Amazon since that is where I was anyway! I have since watched the thing so many times to try to get all the little innuendoes that are present.  If you watch it only once, you'll miss the whole thing - how Rochester not only falls for Jane, but teaches her what love truly is.  He pulls her along through this journey, and she as well, pulls him through his agonizing life to eventually find freedom in God.  The stuff that you can easily miss are things like Rochester rolling his eyes when the subject of governesses comes up, knowing that Jane is hearing every word.  He goes after her to see her response and then, finding her crying, sets out to get even.  He does it again when Lady Ingram demoralizes Jane to scum of the earth practically, and hires the gypsy to tell them things that are not so perfect about themselves (and to see if he's "getting through" to her).In addition, things like how heavy Rochester walks after he and Jane spend the night trying to save Bertha's brother after she tries to kill him, shoulders down, scuffing his feet along the pavement (something Rochester NEVER does - he walks tall and with strength), he looks as if the world is on his back. Not necessarily true to the book in EVERY aspect, this screenplay aptly portrays Rochester and Jane in a very human manner, but never misses a beat in describing how deeply they are rooted into each other.To my fellow purists out there, "adapting" a classic such as Jane Eyre is about as much fun as performing the Schirmer edition of Handel's Messiah instead of the one that Handel actually did himself, but don't pass by this movie.  There are quite a few liberties taken in this version, many of which I didn't quite understand as to why they were taken.  Many of Charlotte's beautiful prose was omitted and more "modern" texts were written.  Just a bit cheeky to do that in my humble opinion. You won't hear Rochester call her an imp or a fairy like in the book, - just accuses her of being a witch a scant amount of times, which takes away from that "magical" feeling that they both shared.In addition, Ms. Welch did change Mr. Eshton's character quite a bit, and interplayed it with the major theme of the story - how alike Rochester and Jane are and have become.  Instead of a politician, she made him a scientist.  He was studying twins and when Jane came back from seeing Aunt Reed, he looks at both Jane and Rochester and "gets it" - points out that they shouldn't be quite so doubtful of two people who can read each other's minds, even though they may be separated, miles in between.  This screenplay further develops the twin theme throughout the movie in such ways as Rochester appears out of nowhere whenever Jane arrives into a room; he's waiting for her when she comes back from Aunt Reed's (but not on a stile like in the book), and all of that "magical" prose that is included in that portion of the book is strangely omitted in favor of Eshton's take on their relationship.  Hmmmmm.In addition, I did have a quibble with what Rochester says to Jane at the end of the movie when he's wanting a wife. It was quite a bit disrespectful and needed to be encased with more verbage from the book to make it fly.  And, most of what Rochester says to Jane is completely omitted. There's just TOO many neat thngs going on at the end of the book to leave it out.  Although Rochester doesn't come out and actually ask Jane to marry him again in the movie (he does in the book), the part where he prays and asks God to help him lead a purer life would have definitely added to the end of this movie.  Also, the screenwriter has Rochester saying "dark" too much.  In light of his situation, "bleak" would have been a better description.Again, honestly, if you buy this video for nothing more than to hear Toby Stephens relay Rochester's escapades in France with Celine, you've done exceptionally well.  Never in the course of movie watching have I heard such an exceptional story teller!  It's kinda funnny really, when they pan back to Ruth Wilson's face - she's just as enthralled with his story-telling as the rest of us!  Sorry, my husband is a vocal music professor and I'm in the music biz so we're aurally oriented in this house - can't help noting talent when we see it!  Stephens is an easy choice for the role because it's one of the many characteristics of Rochester that Jane needs to get to the place where she gains her strength.Sorry for the long review but this movie is quite deep.  Be SURE you don't miss this one.  Don't pass it by thinking it's a stuffy movie that you cannot understand either.  When our cousins at the BBC pull together some of England's finest theatre actors, it's DEFINITELY NOT something to be missed.  I'm a bit aggravated though at the marketing of this video - the cover states, "Just the right amount of heaving bodices."  Really?  Why on earth does EVERYTHING have to be cheapened?  Especially if what is actually there you'll miss if you sneeze!  Masterpiece Theatre needs a new marketing staff.  Other than that, grab this DVD and treat yourself to Stephens' rich baritone voice resonating throughout Thornfield Hall. Great, great stuff - wish it was even longer.  Highly, highly, recommend!

reviewText: It's hard to imagine a better gothic romance than "Jane Eyre" -- and it's harder to imagine a more perfect adaptation than this one.In fact, the 2006 adaptation has pretty much everything going for it -- beautiful settings, eerie direction, sensual romance, and a pair of magnificent leading actors. And it's all wrapped in the misty, haunting atmosphere of a true gothic story -- madwoman in the attic and all.Jane Eyre (Georgie Henley) was an orphan, abused and neglected first by relatives, then by a boarding school. But many years later, Jane (Ruth Wilson) moves on by applying to Thornfield Hall for a governess position, and gets the job. She soon becomes the teacher and friend to the sprightly French girl Adele, but is struck by the dark, almost haunted feeling of her new home.Then she runs into her employer, Mr. Rochester (Toby Stephens), a cynical, embittered man who spends little time at Thornfield. They are slowly drawn together into a powerful love, despite their different social stations -- and Rochester's attentions to a shallow, snotty aristocrat (Christina Cole).But strange things are happening at Thornfield -- stabbings, fires, and a mysterious locked tower. Jane and Rochester finally confess their feelings to each other, but their wedding is interrupted when Rochester's dark past comes to light. And Jane must face losing the man she loves forever...I have to get this out of the way -- I love "Jane Eyre," and have searched for a beautiful, FAITHFUL adaptation for ages. Well, this is it -- a gorgeous, powerful adaptation, which also sticks to the original novel. A few things are shortened or fleshed out, but overall it's not just faithful to the story -- it's faithful to the atmosphere.Director Susanna White doesn't get bogged down in billowy period clothes and wooden acting. Instead, we get the sensual, passionate side of the story, with lots of frustrated romance, sexual tension and a strong bond between two hearts. There are some more lighthearted moments -- wedding shopping, for example -- but also opulant, even dreamlike moments, such as the "owl" jump near the end.And she wraps it in some truly gorgeous visuals, usually in the classic gothic romance style -- looming dark halls, white-robed women, mysterious happenings in the night, misty moors and dark firelit rooms. The entire movie seems bathed in a pale luminous light, as if the sun never quite shines over Thornfield (and Jane and Rochester) until the very end of the story.The story does slow down after the abortive wedding, when Jane flees Thornfield and briefly considers marrying a repressed clergyman. I spent most of the time fidgeting and wondering when Rochester was going to be back. But when Jane departs again, the plot speeds up into a nice, mellow little finale.Ruth Wilson and Toby Stephens are absolutely MADE for these roles. Wilson isn't really pretty, but she has a striking, luminous quality. And she's pretty brilliant at the passionate stuff ("You think that because I am poor, plain, obscure and little... that I have NO HEART!"), but just as good at the quiet moments.And Stephens looks worn and kind of tired for awhile, but he can be gloriously mercurial -- prickly, gruff, fiery and even mischievous. They're both backed by a glorious cast of actors, with Georgie Henley a standout as little Jane, Cole as a snotty fortune-hunter, and Claudia Coulter as a suitably unhinged (yet still beautiful) Bertha.There have been many adaptations of "Jane Eyre," but the misty, haunting 2006 adaptation trumps them all. It's atmospheric, powerful, and passionate.

reviewText: A totally captivating film version of Charlotte Bronte's classic novel.  Three things expecially distinguish this interpretation:  wonderful acting from the entire cast, particularly the spirited Jane (Ruth Wilson) and the tormented but appealing Rochester (Toby Stephens) (their attraction is totally believable!); outstanding production values and attention to period detail; and a script which misses none of the major plot points of the novel, but immediately engages the viewer by begining with Jane's arrival at Thornfield, and gradually revealing her early life as back story, rather than developing the tale chronologically.It should be noted that the film omits the explicit Protestant Christian aspects of the novel (and Jane's attendant prejudices), at least directly, while leaving intact Jane's defiantly independent sense of her own worth and her deep sense of what is due to other people.  It might be fair to say that this is a fundamental betrayal of the novel--as deeply religious as Jane is--but there is no question that as a film story per se, this was the correct decision.I would not be surprised to find that this seductive film leads many viewers to read the novel, but it stands on its own as a well-made work of art.

reviewText: Reading the numerous positive reviews of the 2006 television production of "Jane Eyre" one could be led to expect the definitive version of Charlotte Bront's classic novel. It is not. In fact, of all the six noteworthy adaptations which have been made of the novel since the Welles/Fontaine movie in 1944 this is by far the worst. And all the positive reviews must have been written by people who either do not know the novel, do not appreciate it or for whom a lavish production with stunning settings and two attractive leading actors is enough to send them into ecstasies. Admirers of the novel, however, and lovers of good period movies must cringe at this "Jane Eyre" (as they dare to call it).Although the length of this adaptation would allow for great faithfulness to the novel, many of the novel's most crucial scenes are either deleted, severely changed or replaced by scenes which have nothing whatever to do with the novel. The same goes for the language: The novel has become immortal for the unsurpassed beauty and originality of the dialogues between Rochester and Jane. In the 2006 version however, nearly all the novel's beautiful lines have been substituted with trite and stupid ones. And if this were not already bad enough, also the characters are portrayed in a way as to make you wonder if anybody of the cast and crew ever cared to read the novel. Whosever fault it may be, the actors', the scriptwriter's or the director's - but the fact is that Toby Stephens' Rochester and Ruth Wilson's Jane have nothing in common with the novel's main characters. Toby Stephens in particular does not resemble at all the charismatic, masterful, imperious, moody and irresistible Rochester of the novel. Where are Rochester's torment, his regrets about his past, his struggle with his conscience, and where is his wit? Played by Toby Stephens, the attractive, complex and three-dimensional character of the novel has become a one-dimensional weakling. Ruth Wilson tries her best, but neither does she physically fit the part of the small and elfin-like Jane, nor does the bold, self-confident and outspoken young female she portrays render the true character of the novel's shy and guarded heroine.Furthermore, instead of showing the subtle gradual development of the special relationship between the main characters - a love born out of the affinity of souls - the filmmakers just emphasize the sexual attraction between Rochester and Jane, thereby reducing one of the most complex and interesting love relationships in English literature to high school movie level. Apparently the filmmakers considered the emphasis on the sexual element as an appropriate means of modernizing the novel and securing the interest of a younger and supposedly shallow audience in the story.  And this is exactly the main offence of this production: Of course every director is perfectly free to adopt a novel according to his or her own notion, to change the plot, change the dialogues, change the characters and to call that film "Jane Eyre" - but to set that movie in the period of the 1850ies and to completely disregard that period's language and behaviour, etiquette and sense of decency is just plain bad movie making. This Jane Eyre is a silly soap opera in the disguise of a period movie in which the actors talk and behave as if they had been put in the costumes of the 1850ies by mistake. The most striking example of that is the scene after the aborted wedding - the novel's pivotal scene in which Jane won't allow even the slightest attempt of Rochester's caressing her. Considering what they did to the rest of the novel it should come as no surprise that this scene is completely butchered in the 2006 production. Rochester lies on top of Jane, they kiss repeatedly and seem both near to taking off their clothes. Not only is this an outrage to Charlotte Bront, it is also a complete misrepresentation of how people would behave in the middle of the 19th century.There have been many beautiful adaptations of famous novels in the last decade, which were true both to the literary models as well as to the period in which the novels play and which have charmed the audience without their having to be sexed up. The makers of the latest version of Jane Eyre unfortunately failed to recognize what is timeless in the novel and what is unchangeably bound to its time. This TV production is therefore a striking example of a senseless and totally superfluous attempt to modernize a classic novel. As a period drama it is a complete failure - as an adaptation of Jane Eyre it is a slap in the face of its author.If you simply want a better Jane Eyre you can take any of the other productions - if you want the definitive Jane Eyre there is only one to watch: the '83 BBC mini series with Zelah Clarke and Timothy Dalton. This Jane Eyre is in every respect the very opposite of the 2006 series. It has a brilliant script, the dialogues are straight from the novel and the plot is followed with the greatest possible accuracy. Moreover, it has two leading actors who truly capture the essence of the characters they portray. Timothy Dalton in particular is a revelation as Rochester. Like no other actor before him or after him he renders all the different facets of Rochester's character and does so to perfection. Zelah Clarke is equally excellent in the role of Jane in that she portrays exactly the Jane of the novel and does not try to make her bolder, more modern and more feminist than described by Charlotte Bront. The interplay between Clarke and Dalton is wonderful and they render all the passion and intensity of the novel without their having to fall back on the means of modern eroticism and without once digressing from the literary model. This superb production is and will remain the only true, the definitive "Jane Eyre".

reviewText: After her stunning and brilliant Direction of BLEAK HOUSE last season, Susanna White creates a visually stark and beautiful to look at version of JANE EYRE. Just plain ikky.JANE EYRE is difficult to translate well onto screen because her major relationship in the book is NOT with Rochester, it is with God, it permeates her upbringing, her time at Rochester's house, her struggles, her time at the house of the Pastor & his sisters, her refusal of missionary work, and the end.  Bronte was a brilliant, incisive religious thinker who used this story to pinpoint that a relationship with God can be a reason to relieve yourself from mission work for the wrong reasons, just as it can be a drive to deny your heart's wish because that, too is wrong.Even if you take out bits of the story, you can retain this mindset.  When you remove this mindset, which THIS gloriously costumed, photographed, and settinged production does, you deteriorate the characters into "Jane and Rochester Rock the Canopy Bed".  That should have been the title of this one... so very WB network (or now CW network).This is my favorite book, & I've seen - several times - almost every version made of this story, and have a collection of it.  Not only do I not want this version, I could not make myself watch all of it - I kept turning it off and coming back.  I was disgusted by watching Jane and Rochester snog on the sofa and put down Miss Fairfax.So wrongheaded, Bronte must be spinning in her grave like a silkworm junkie that needs a fix.  JANE EYRE is the story of two physically unattrative people, drawn together by understanding of their souls.  There has not been ONE version yet that has cast BOTH roles this way, and I defy a major studio to do it.  (The closest was probably Zefferelli's version.)Ruth Wilson, tall, elegantly slender, not beautiful, but in every way attractive by today's standards, and Toby Stephens, the greasy-haired six-pack ab workout hottie, are both about as wrong as you can get physically.  The 40s version with Welles and Fontaine took tremendous liberties with the book and they're both attractive, but they both eminate the souls found in the book in a production that just reeks of the spirit.But the real corker here is the way Rochester is written and played. He might as well be mubbling his way through a Sam Sheppard play!  If you are seriously REVIEWING this DVD you HAVE to distinquish between lusting after Toby like pre-pubescent teens & Rochester the timeless character.  Good young actor, nice bod, completely wrong for Rochester.  Even Gorgous Timothy Dalton was better because he had the right mental stuff going on.)  Best Rochester ever is Ciarin Hinds in the version with Samatha Morton.  HE is still too tall, too handsome, but WOW.  100% got the book down.  (Morton, on the other hand, a fine actress, looks the part but sneers and smirks like a demi-monde courtesan... wierd, wierd choices.)So this missed effort - I gave it a 3 - Why so high?  The production values are that high.  Really, that detail correct, that beautiful to behold.  Which makes the sum of the parts that much more insufferably frustrating.  Poor Charlotte, still misunderstood.

reviewText: I have nothing but praise for this realization of Jane Eyre.  I saw what aired on the BBC as "Episode 3," the third hour, last October in Scotland and was on pins and needles waiting for Masterpiece Theater to bring Jane Eyre to my TV.  Jane's childhood seems to go by quickly, but her experiences and associations are never forgotten and this adaptation makes connections throughout.  Ruth Wilson's Jane is completely fresh and true.  She is on screen throughout and is always in character, her face always expressive.  Toby Stephens is also a powerful Rochester.  Yes, he's handsome!  But he brings more of Rochester's humor and intensity to the role than I've seen in other actors, and he is "eyes-open," a Rochester whose past is never far from his mind -- very interesting.  The script ties in incidents beautifully and uses much of the text of the novel.  It is very clever.  There is a scene in the novel that is one of my favorites that is altered here but to me works better for purposes of this program:  Jane returns to Thornfield after attending Mrs. Reed -- in the novel she is overcome with emotion and tries to sneak past Rochester unseen.  This is used earlier in the dramatization, when she unexpectedly comes upon Rochester watching dragonflies on the grounds of Thornfield.  However, her speech ("Thank you for your great kindness") on returning from Mrs. Reed's deathbed -- is used intact and in context.  Anyway -- it is a very good production in my opinion.  I have edited this review to add praise for the entire cast.  In particular, praise for Pam Ferris in giving Grace Poole depth.  The BBC website, in its section on this production of Jane Eyre, includes Grace Poole's story, written by Ms. Ferris.  The soundtrack is beautiful and brings me to tears!  I hope that we will someday have a CD of Rob Lane's soundtracks.  He also composed the soundtrack for "To the Ends of the Earth."Make note of the other reviews here!  You may wish to wait for a coming version that includes the extra features included in the British release.

reviewText: "Masterpiece Theater" has long been a benchmark in bringing quality British TV to American viewers.  With a prestigious history, some legendary programs--including "Upstairs, Downstairs" and "I, Claudius"--have found acclaim, awards, and international audiences.  Of late, "Masterpiece Theater" has been showcasing some ambitious literary adaptations with mixed results.  Last season's high point, and a must for any lover of film, was the flawless adaptation of Charles Dickens' "Bleak House."  A triumph in every regard, and featuring Emmy nominated turns by Charles Dance and Gillian Anderson, this program should be essential viewing for those that value literate, classy and wildly entertaining TV.  This season's offerings have included "To The Ends Of The Earth" (an adaptation of William Golding's seafaring trilogy--'Rites Of Passage,' 'Close Quarters' and 'Fire Down Below'), a robust new version of Charlotte Bronte's "Jane Eyre," a reimagining of Bram Stoker's "Dracula," and the swan song of Helen Mirren's Jane Tennison in "Prime Suspect 7."What can one say about "Jane Eyre" that hasn't been said before?  Being familiar with the novel and countless prior adaptations, I'll admit that I wasn't all that excited to revisit what I consider to be a very familiar tale.  However, I diligently sat down to watch the latest 2 part "Masterpiece Theater" production.  And, boy, am I ever glad that I did.  While there are some liberties taken with the source material, that's to be expected.  Anyone who envisions every adaptation of a novel to be a literal translation is denying the power of the film medium to create new and enduring art.  In fact, it often annoys me when people carp on how something is different in lieu of accepting the merits of the interpretation.  This "Jane Eyre" succeeds so well due to the credible romantic relationship, the intelligent screenplay, and the genuinely haunting quality of the central mystery.While this version breezes past Jane's difficult childhood, it effectively settles into the heart of the story--when Jane takes a position at Thornfield Hall.  Jane becomes fascinated by her new employer, Mr. Rochester.  The two interact believably, and as Jane gets past Rochester's gruff exterior and erratic mood swings--she starts to have feelings for the man.  Part One of this miniseries details the evolving, but chaste, relationship.  In addition, the mysterious goings-on at Thornfield are excellently depicted.  I was riveted by everything in this first part--particularly the intelligent banter between the two leads and the underlying sense of dread that exists in the manor.  Easily 5 stars, the first half of this miniseries is flawless.  In Part Two, physical romance blossoms and secrets are revealed in a very satisfying way.  However, as "Jane" fans know--there are still plenty of obstacles in the way of true love.  As the story wanders away from Thornfield, the program loses some of its momentum and its magic.  It's still a good adaptation--but when the leads are separated, it loses a bit of its spark.In case you haven't guessed, I was thoroughly impressed by Ruth Wilson and Toby Stephens, as Jane and Rochester respectively.  Wilson is the perfect Jane--intelligent and appealing.  It's hard to imagine someone not falling in love with her, she's so sensible and caring.  Stephens does a terrific job, as well.  Playing the tortured Rochester, he is a trapped soul that's yearning, but unable, to escape.  While referred to in the dialogue as ugly (which he's not), it is also easy to see why this man would be a challenge for and an equal to Jane. reviewText: With the 1995 adaptation of Pride and Prejudice the BBC set a new standard for literaty adaptations. Fortunately it's one that they've been able live up to, Most recently in this recent adaptation of Jane Eyre.Overall it's a highly recommended adaptation. Is it 100% true to the novel? No but  since that's not really what I look for in an adaptation. The question is, does it stand on it's own merits? Yes.Ruth Wilson is really likable as Jane Eyre and I think that she has a exciting career ahead of her. I look foreward to seeing what she does next. Her Jane is less plain than others are and probably less so than Bronte wrote the character. From the begining there's a sparkle in her eye. She's less repressed, and all the brains and spirit that are initially well hidden in Bront's Jane are bubbling just beneath the surface of Wilson's.  Likewise, Toby Stephen's Rochester is younger and better looking than I usually imagine the character. But his harshness is tempered with a wonderfully sardonic wit. He's a man who has had a difficult life but he looks back on it with a rueful sense of humor.Once or twice it seemed as if the filmmakers were trying to make the film "sexy" in unnecessary ways. At one point Jane saves Mr. Rochester's life. When he  thanks her, he asks to shake her hand. Instead he takes both her hands in both of his and moves in very close. I was truely expecting a make-out scene. It just seemed more Supermarket Checkout Line Romance, then Victorian Gothic Romance. It's a romantic story to begin with- no need to turn it into a bodice ripper. These scenes aren't needed but the chemistry between the leads makes them work.A few reviewers have critized the two leads for being too attractive, betraying the idea of the book. However that assumes that the book is about ugly people falling in love. It's not. It's about a woman growing and establishing herself in life without the benefit of money, social connections or an exceptional physical appearance. Jane Eyre had endured as a work of literature due to the romantic and at times suspensful nature of the plot, the strong sense of atmosphere, a sense of with and intelligence and above all an immensely likable heroine (despite or perhaps because of her lack of glamour) While it leaves out a few potions of the novel, this film preserves the important qualities.

reviewText: I am a period drama aficionado and count "North & South," "Pride & Prejudice" and "Wives & Daughters" among my top favorites. I was keenly awaiting this new version of Jane Eyre as I count the earlier version starring Timothy Dalton and Zelah Clarke as one of my favorite dramas.This "Jane Eyre" has notable differences to earlier versions and they are, in most cases, good differences.  The same attention to detail, care, fine locations, engaging storyline, and superb acting and production values that you would expect from the BBC are present this version of JE. The cast is led by Toby Stephens (a favorite since his "Tenant of Wildfell Hall" days) and newcomer Ruth Wilson. Most of us already know the story and I am pleased to report that the screenwriter has done a good job of staying true (in most cases) to the book.  The screenplay and locations lend to the gothic and atmospheric feel of this version, and there is some beautiful cinematography throughout.I quite like Toby Stephens as Rochester. He is very different from Timothy Dalton's (my favorite version) portrayal but is good all the same. I think perhaps I wish he (Toby) was a little more stern or a little more of a brooding presence. I always thought of Rochester as a brooding, mercurial hero in my mind since I read the book years ago, and this difference between the book Rochester and Toby's portrayal doesn't always mesh.  While watching I found myself wondering what it would've been like if Richard Armitage (from "North & South") had played Rochester instead!  Ruth Wilson is pitch perfect, on the other hand. Her Jane is both strong and intelligent, but vulnerable all the same.  Francesca Annis, Christina Cole, Tara Fitzgerald and Georgie Henley are quite good in their supporting roles.I suppose one thing that may set the purists on fire are some of the changes (call it "modernizing" the story?) made to this adaptation.  There is certainly more kissing and passion - only alluded to and not often seen in the book and earlier versions - no doubt to make it appeal to modern audiences.  Although I like some kissing here and there, I must admit that "less is more" in this case. This Rochester is also far more likeable and appealing than his predecessors - and in my heart I wish he was a little more complex.  I like this version - not love it - and because of this I will only give 4 stars.  If I had loved it like I love "North & South" and even the Timothy Dalton/Zelah Clarke "Jane Eyre," then it would've gotten 5 stars in my book.I do recommend this adaptation to fans of period drama, especially if you are a Bronte fan.  It is well worth seeing and I have no doubt that many of you will become Toby Stephens and Ruth Wilson fans by the end.  I believe that it is a fine addition to any British period drama fans dvd library.

reviewText: This item has been on my wish list for awhile, but, being on a tight budget, I have yet to purchase it. (That will be rectified within days!) I've seen several versions of this classic (not all by any means), and I've read the book multiple times. Up until now, I have to say that my favorite production has been the Timothy Dalton/Zelah Clarke version. It is absolutely true to the book. Even the dialogue of that version goes verbatim to the book much of the time. But, in all honesty, I have to say that after recording this version on my DVR this weekend, it's become my clear favorite. While there are minor deviations from the book, the heart of the story still remains intact. And the minor deviations do give this version a fresher approach. What I most love about this version is the passion displayed between Jane and Rochester. Hollywood could certainly take some pointers here. There are no inappropriate scenes, there is no R-rated material, but it is certainly not lacking in passion. The scenes in the flashbacks of Jane and Rochester that precede her leaving after the failed wedding are steamy, yet tasteful. And who among us hasn't thought that such passion would have indeed been a part of their relationship? Both Ruth Wilson and Toby Stephens (he is gorgeous) were well suited to their respective roles, and played them to the hilt. I especially like his somewhat dry wit, and the banter that the two exchange at times.As far as any negatives, since I've only seen this broadcast on Ovation I can't be sure if there is any material deleted. However, basing my comments on what I've seen, the only real negative comments I can make about this version are  1) The part of the story that centers around St. John and his sisters is much less detailed than in the Timothy Dalton/Zelah Clarke version. That's not necessarily a negative, but it is much more condensed in this version.2) If one hasn't read the book or is otherwise familiar with the story, there may be some questions about Rochester's injuries toward the end. There is only a brief description of what happened at Thornfield, and no explanation or scenes depicting how he sustained his injuries. It is, therefore, to be assumed I suppose by anyone who may not already be familiar with the details. This version also leaves the impression that he remains blind. That was somewhat disappointing.In this reveiwer's humble opinion, the pros far outnumber the cons for this version. On a final note, another huge plus for this version is the grandeur of the scenery and the beautiful, sometimes haunting musical score. Of course, one would expect both from Masterpiece Theatre and the BBC. As always, they delivered with full force on this excellently done timeless classic.Addendum:As I mentioned in my initial review, I had, at that time, only seen this on Ovation. I ordered the DVD, and have now watched it. As I suspected, there were some scenes deleted from the Ovation production as there almost always is on network TV in order to fit alloted time slots. The scenes that were deleted, however, while adding to the overall feel and grandeur of the production, were not critical to the storyline. But I feel the need to add a little to my review now that I have seen the DVD. While I still love this version and am most happy to have it as a part of my video collection, I do feel that it is lacking in some minor details that, for me, would have enhanced the production. I will preface this by stating that I am very much a 'detail person.' For me, I prefer to know the how and why and when of events and not to be left assuming. If you are not a detail person, then these things probably don't matter to you.1)After the fire in Rochester's bedroom where the wonderful romantic scene takes place he wraps his robe around her and tells her '..we agreed you'd never be cold again.' Okay, when did that conversation take place? 2)There is a scene which takes place the morning following the fire when Jane learnes that he has left to attend a house party. When Mrs. Fairfax comes to the table, Jane appears to have in her hand either a necklace or some memento, which she quickly puts in her pocket as if she doesn't wish Mrs. Fairfax to see it. What is it? And what are the details regarding it? 3)After the scream in the night when all the guests are alarmed and gather in the hall Rochester speaks to them, calming their fears, and then tells them to go back to bed. We see Jane wipe up the blood that dripped from his injured hand (we are not told how that happened) and then we see her waiting fully dressed in her bedroom. At his knock on the door, she answers 'I'm ready.' He obviously conveyed to her that he wished her assistance. But that is omitted. 4)Toward the end when Jane returns to Thornfield, the details are very sketchy as to what happened to Rochester regarding the fire. Nothing is mentioned of his injuries. Jane obviously doesn't even know he's blind until she sees him some distance away outside Ferndean. At no time is it mentioned that he can see at least a little. Yet during the scene at the end when she sits in his lap with her face very close to his, she asked, "Can you see me?" and he nods in the affirmative.Now, having read the book and seen other versions of the story on film, I know most of these details. But I'm sure there are some who have not read the book and are not familiar with the story at all. For me, if that were the case, there would be some unanswered questions regarding these details I've mentioned.Those, for me, are the negative aspects of this production. Maybe I'm just spoiled by the Timothy Dalton/Zelah Clarke version, which is so detailed. Having stated all this, I do still love this version. I like the fact that Rochester seems to have a fondness for Adele, even though he says he doesn't like children. It is also obvious in this version that he does not care for either Blanche or her snobbish family and attitudes. He never states in this version that he offered his attentions to her in order to make Jane as madly in love with him as he was with her, which he does state in the book.Rochester is a wounded soul. The sadness definitely comes through. He comes across as a complex character; gentlemanly and refined, displaying at times a somewhat dry wit. Yet at other times one can see the intense sadness that masks his face.My initial rating of this production still stands. I love it in spite of the omissions, although I would very much have liked for those things I've mentioned to have been addressed.If someone out there is not familiar with the story and this is the first version you are to view, I would suggest you familiarize yourself somewhat with the overall aspects of the story, especially regarding Rochester's injuries and how they were sustained at the end.

reviewText: I have already written a review on this site advocating readers/lovers of Bronte's novel who want a FAITHFUL version of Jane Eyre to buy the Timothy Dalton/Zelah Clarke version as it is (especially with deleted scenes restored to the DVD version, making it truly a complete filmed version of the novel) the MOST true to Bronte's book in casting/acting, scenes played out, etc.  However, while I wasn't wild about this version the first time viewing it, I did enjoy it much better the second time through, having taped it off Masterpiece Theatre.  I think that Toby Stephens and Ruth Wilson did a fine acting job, though, as others have stated here, he doesn't truly physically fit Rochester, and he also doesn't seem to have some of the edginess/hysteria that Dalton portrayed so well in the scene when Jane leaves him.  That scene, shown in a flashback in this version, has Stephens and Wilson steamily smooching on a bed - her lips are saying 'no' while simultaneously saying 'yes.'  This, to me, while very romantic and, probably in the director/screenwriter's choice, meant to show that Jane's temptation was great not to leave him and to become his mistress (which clearly WAS Rochester's intention in the novel, no matter the silly line inserted in this version that he would live with her as 'brother and sister' - something clearly NOT intended by the Rochester of Bronte's creation), the book clearly states that Jane will NOT kiss the 'husband of Bertha Mason' and Zelah Clarke very well shows how she had to steel herself against Rochester's attempts to break her down with kisses - though NOT in the bedroom.  No self respecting person in that day and age, especially someone who cared for their respectability and who would want to find employment again in a respectable household, would have dared to let a man who was not their husband alone in their bedroom.  This fact alone 'compromised' men and women into marriage proposals, whether things happened or not.  (Or have none of you EVER read Regency fiction?)  Even as recently as the 1940s and 50s, it was common for women in gals-only hotels to have to leave their apartment doors open when having a male friend visit - if they were unmarried.  These social mores were clearly stronger and more evident in Bronte's day.  Since Jane now KNEW that Rochester was NOT free to marry her, she would not have dared, divorce being almost unheard of in that day, to allow him into her room alone after she was enlightened about the existence of Bertha.  In the novel, her steeling herself and making herself appear 'cold' to Rochester is the only way she can preserve her own sanity and self from giving into the temptation of his suggestion to run away with him to become his mistress.  She tells him that everything is changed, and that she must change too - and that she loves him, when he desperately pleads with her that she never did truly love him, but that that was the last time she would be able to say it.  I reread that scene in the book after watching this version again the second time and the Clarke/Dalton version got it right - Dalton clearly shows the wildness and desperation Rochester is going through while Clarke shows Jane's steely determination not to give in.  I find it much more heartbreaking in that version, the parting scene, following as it does, Bronte's novel, than this more modernized version.There were also quite a few liberties taken with the speech in the novel - the Dalton version remains the most faithful in this department as well.  For me, the best parts of this version where when they kept to the words as written by Bronte.  I also did not care for the occult game played by the guests in Rochester's house - this was also not in the book and would have been abhorrent to Bronte's puritanical upbringing - and it was too bad that the director would not allow Toby Stephens to try his hand at playing the gypsy as Dalton did, which is what Rochester did in the book, rather than having a real gypsy brought in. Helen Burns and her important influence on Jane's outlook and character are also reduced to almost nothing.  I don't know if this is because many people at large have an antipathy to Christianity, but the part of the book where Jane describes her hunger for human love being so bad that she would endure things such as having an animal kick her or her arm broken, etc. countered by Helen's calm, wise advice on not putting too much emphasis on human love in this life, but rather focusing on the love of God - this to me seems to be a crucial scene when seen in light of Jane's drawing upon her spiritual resources to find the strength to reject Rochester's proposal to run away with him.  I found it sad that the screenwriter could not have considered at least inserting some part of that aspect of Jane and Helen's relationship in the film.All that being stated, there were touches in this film that I thought were nice - Jane's clear forgiveness of the unforgivable Aunt Reed was nicely portrayed and written, though again, not quite true to the description in the book, by Ruth Wilson, showing her generosity of heart.  Stephens' acting during the Rochester blind scenes was especially sensitive and heartfelt. I also liked that this version kept all three of Jane's cousins, though it would have been nice to have a St. John Rivers that truly was blond with the 'grecian profile' which the actor, while good, who played him, did not have either that Or was better looking than Toby Stephens, something which really should be considered in casting St. John Rivers.  His physique and face is part of the reason why Miss Oliver is so obsessed with him!  Again, the guy in the Dalton version who portrayed Rivers was much better cast - both in looks (as what was 'beautiful' in those days) and also in his portrayal of Rivers' hardness of heart and determination.  I thought it was a nice touch to show Jane and Rochester's 'happy ending' with their family together for the portrait at the end.  Most versions either just leave it to the viewer's imagination or just show them sitting together sedately by some water while quoting Jane's comments on Rochester gaining back his sight by the time their first born comes into the world so that he can see his son has inherited his large brilliant eyes.That all being said, while Dalton's version still remains my favorite, this one has beautiful cinematography and has the spirit of the book and has done a nice job with some of the backstory with Rochester and Bertha, making it probably the second best version in recent years - though for me, Orson Welles and George C. Scott approach Rochester's true physical outward appearance than some of the more handsome actors that have played him recently.  Ciaran Hinds comes closest of the recent ones, but his voice doesn't have the 'rich baritone' described of Rochester in the book.  Too bad NONE Of the versions ever showed Rochester and Blanche Ingram singing together.  I will still love Dalton's first, Orson Welles second, and probably this third of all the versions that have been made.

reviewText: Channel-surfing a few weeks ago, I happened upon the second half of the 2006 BBC production of Jane Eyre on Public Television.  I have seen the 1944, 1973, and 1983 film versions, and read the novel numerous times.  The 2006 version is the winner by a mile, for the following reasons: 1. The acting and casting is superb in every instance. 2. This is the first film "Jane" that looks and acts 18, as well as the first Mr. Rochester that was the right age (according to the novel, "just past youth", late 30's.) 3.  Filmed entirely on location, complete authenticity in that respect.  4. The first film version where I could believe the costumes. 5."Adele" looked French (although the actress was not), she also spoke French perfectly, and her character was portrayed more fully than in other versions. 5. The best presentation of the most important plot points of the novel i.e. good screenplay.  The written word and a film are 2 totally different media.  Film is primarily visual.  This was not a word-for-word reading from the novel, but a skillfull transfer to the visual medium, true to the situations and intense relationships portrayed in the novel.  6. The only film version that not only acknowledges but affirms the Christian content found in the novel.One flaw, small to the point of insignificance; Blanche Ingram, in the novel, has black hair and dark eyes, not blonde and blue-eyed, as in the film. But the main point is established still, Blanche's beauty, arrogance, and shallowness are portrayed well.In summary, for the above reasons, this film works! Sit back after a day at work, and watch a magical tale of true love unfold.

reviewText: All of the film versions of Jane Eyre are flawed; some mildly, some fatally. All films based on masterpieces have the Sisyphian challenge of collecting the vapors of imagination into one mass, giving it form, and moving it against reality.The power of this story is derived from the steadfast integrity of its heroine: To emerge as noble as she does binds us inexorably to her plight. Jane is one of English literature's great characters.The years at Lowood School are given short shrift in all of the filmed versions, but not in the book. Jane's relationship with Helen Burns, Miss Temple and books is pivotal to her salvation from her days with Mrs. Reed, her miscreants, and Brocklehurst and Co. Brocklehurst is finally vilified, but not before he facilitates Helen's death from consumption. This occupies a quarter of the novel. Why is this spiritual-intellectual-tragic foundation universally truncated on film?One of the crucial scenes is the one in which Rochester proposes. Compare all of the versions with this touchstone. The Welles-Fontaine version is ridiculous. The Dalton-Clarke scene is austere and passionless. The Jayson-Cusack energy is cold and stilted. The Scott-York proposal is not credible. The Hinds-Morton is well acted but strangely awkward. The Hurt-Gainsbourg rendition is good, but bitter. This Stephens-Wilson interpretation is convincing and powerful. Wilson's Jane is the most polished of the collection of plain-(and not so plain)-Janes: Her basic integrity the most richly developed and convincing. Wilson, Gainsbourg, and Morton are the most accomplished thespians to date. Clarke, Cusack, and York never disappear into the 1830s. Fontaine looks as though she wafted out of an opium den. Virginia Bruce's Jane is a joke.All of the masters of Thornfield go wanting in one way or another. Fault the script and direction, not their acting skills. Most are consummate actors. In none of the pairings has the string from Edward's rib to Jane's seemed genuine.The "Just the right amount of heaving bodies" on the marquee, in this BBC production, is embarrassing and inappropriate, as are the bedroom antics. Too bad one cannot edit DVDs as one could VHS tapes. Excise the 21st century from the 19th.Still, after picking scabs off of all of the versions, this heals with the least scar tissue.The denouement is appropriate (a bit contrived), not awkward or abrupt as in the book and the other productions.All of the nine films have their individual strong and weak points. With multiple viewings, one tends to amalgamate the strengths of all to fashion a satisfying whole. It would be wonderful to have, finally, one definitive whole.Alas, this is the most engaging of the lot. It wears very well under the scrutiny of multiple viewings. Wilson's skills are impressively subtle. Examine the scene in which St John confronts Jane with her true identity. Watch her breathing whilst she remains expressionless. Beautifully done.Magnificent production, scabs and all.

reviewText: [from Masterpiece Theatre, 2006]Eyre : I'm sorry sir, I did not ask permission to read the books.Rochester : (to the effect) You don't need to ask permission Jane . . after all, you're a thinking person . . blah-bi-di-blah-blah-blahYeah.This adaptation is mined with expositive anvils. It's not for anyone accustomed to the gifted authors who are *masters* of language, that have dominated American cable in recent years. In that respect it's oddly out of it's time. Which is a shame because the camera work and overall production values are great and Ruth Wilson is terrific; heartfelt and sympathetic... but that's about as far as it goes. Which isn't her fault.  She is hampered by shoddy writing and comparatively light weight conflict.Somewhere along the line, someone got the bright idea that Stephens -- who does an awful lot of smirking and frowning here -- should play Rochester like he never really means the coarse  . . . no, actually Bront's coarseness is largely removed from this version . . . maybe *objectionable* is a better word . . yeah *objectionable,* things he's says, almost apologizing for them. Signaling to the audience, not to be alarmed, this really is a romantic, good-guy.But that's only partly true.In Bront's  book, Rochester is a manic, indulged, game playing, liar. Sure he's *really* besotted with the governess, and has a looney wife in the tower, all of which creates a lot of stress. But how many men would play out their sexual/romantic pursuit in this twisted, convoluted way?  His eccentricities, changeable moods and ethical elasticity are also part of his *character,* and provide much of the dark, quirky menace and mystery that drive the story. Both for us and for Jane.  The reasons *why*, can never be completely answered.It seems this last point did not sit well with writer Sandy Welch, who sets about scrubbing away any trace of dirt and ambiguity from Edward's character, by creating scenes so ham-fisted, it's virtually impossible to imagine Bront wrote them. Example: a haughty house guest accuses him of too much compassion., explaining *she's* not bothered by the fact that some people are born rich and others poor. To which Rochester frowns disapprovingly, and declares the conversation tiresome.  In fact, at the point we meet Rochester he's long abandoned philanthropic notions in favor of dallying in "sensual pleasure," (a conversation absent in this version.) He even calls Jane out for calling him on it. But even if you decide Rochester has since become more politically correct (Welsh's assertion not Bront's), is it wise to pointedly cue in the audience at this stage in the story? To a similar effect, Welsh invents a Ouija board scene where Rochester manipulates the board so Blanche spells out the word "h-e-a-r-t-l-e-s-s."And what she *doesn't* invent is not much better. In this version, Rochester hires a gypsy to play the fortune teller.  Upon discovery, he flat-out tells Jane, he just wanted to know what she was thinking, then they both make fun of the house guests.  Why bother contriving all that, if he had no problem spilling the beans anyway? Then after coming off a wonderful moment of indignance at being prompted to "talk nonsense," Wilson's Jane must now appear dense, unable to decipher Edward's obvious adoration of her.And nowhere in *any* of this, is there any seeming awareness that only a perverse mind would engage in such play to begin with.And so on... his relationship with Adele is handled much the same way.The results are an Edward so sanitized and transparent, it seriously reduces the conflict and character contrast in the story, flattening the dynamic. We're also left with a much less interesting character, if not a confusing one.  And without the risk, his contrast to St. John Rivers, and the meaning of Jane's decision to return to Thornfield, is oversimplified.There's also far less testing of the waters, during the 1st interviews, and toe-to-toe challenge which is not incidental to the story.  In fact it's the hinge on which their relationship builds and an important facet that makes *these* characters unique.I will admit the proposal scene (one of the best in this version) had a lot of life to it and Stephens was at his best here. But at points even the changed dialogue landed awkward, and after building to the kiss, he lands one . . . right at the *side* of her mouth.As others mentioned, the Gateshead-Lowood years are inexplicably truncated. Though artfully done they are unsubstantial in providing the grim context. This includes child abuse in the shape of beatings, humiliation, unfounded accusations and a relentless barrage of damning judgment, aimed at breaking the spirit of orphaned youths . . . in the guise of saving their souls. At times Wilson's gravitas compensate for these deficiencies, but that can only stretch so far.This adaptation is also light on stricture -- either her adherence to or questioning of it, as well as her consuming struggle with conscience; her attempts to weigh what she has been taught, against what she is learning.And please no purist finger pointing, I firmly believe one can create too faithful an adaptation of a 500 page novel. But in the end you have to at least make choices that are consistent with the tone, along with other components that define a story.Otherwise cliches are used to punch up the romantic angle, such as back lighting during the "after the fire" scene, creating dreamy silhouettes that are more evocative of the sweet discoveries in "Romeo and Juliet," than the dangerous sexuality in "Jane Eyre."Elsewhere in this version St. John, upon discovering the exhausted Jane, *gracefully* stretched out on a rock, simply lifts her up and carries her to safety.The '83 adaptation (which I discovered only recently) on the other hand, though flawed, does not omit the dirty bits. There, after weakened, dejected Jane (Zelah Clarke) tries to trade her gloves for a-day-old biscuit; she is shamed and thrown out of the bakery. She winds up shoveling gruel into her mouth, meant for pigs, with her bare fingers. Then starved, frozen and delirious, she bangs on a door during a storm.  In tears she yells incoherently at the housekeeper, who turns her away. After which St. John finds her.There is nothing graceful or visually appealing about *this* picture. The consequences are clear. Jane has fallen a lot further down  through knowing Mr. Rochester, the man she pledged her heart to.Pluses against minuses, I'd recommend the '83 adaptation. Be warned the production values are weak, the occasional scoring abominable, the camera work unimaginative and a few scenes needed to be reworked, even after good starts (but ONLY a few.)  Likely due to time constraints and/or momentary directorial assy-ness. Which is forgivable. This one probably had the lowest budget per hour.Still THAT one, which DOES use much of Bront's  gutsier language, tells THIS particular story much better. Timothy Dalton is walking thunder and provides an edgy pulse that is decidedly Bront. However while giving a bigger performance, he is overall, less mannered, and seemingly more relaxed in the vagaries of Edward's skin. He relishes the games, embracing the darkness and duality of this character, rather than apologizing for it. Yet his tender moments are both real and surprising, and genuinely rewarding.Given that the BBC/MT has, in recent years, produced gritty works involving female protagonists like, "The Virgin Queen" and "The Final Act," without flinching, this bloodless, patronizing, girly-girl treatment of "Eyre" is puzzling and very disappointing. Next time they feel the itch to give Bront the Austen treatment, I hope they'll come to their senses and hand the project over to HBO, where they're under no obligation to tamper with essentials. Call me a cynic but I think economic  concerns trumped artistic ones, due to an avalanche of competitors jockeying for airtime and dvd sales.
